data.title: External terminal set to Cmder, "Open in Command Prompt" doesn't open in correct directory
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Added system environment path to my Cmder install
2. In settings.json I have `"terminal.external.windowsExec": "Cmder.exe"`
3. When I right click on a folder in the Explorer and select "Open in Command Prompt" it launches Cmder, but doesn't auto-navigate me to the directory I just selected on. It opens me at the default Cmder directory instead

data.title: Custom file association breaks VSCode command line registry entry.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6, 1.6.1
- OS Version: MS Windows 7 Enterprise SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the latest stable VSCode 1.6.1
2. Check

> `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\vscode\shell\open\command`

registry entry, it should say:

> `"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe" "%1"`
1. Add a custom file association that has a VSCode entry in:

> `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\*.custom\OpenWithProgids`
1. Try and open a _**.custom_\* file. It should open fine.
2. Close VSCode
3. Check`HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\vscode\shell\open\command`, it now says:

> `"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe" --open-url "%1"`

`--open-url` option does not work on Windows, double-clicking your *.custom files opens VSCode, but the file's not opened.

2. shift+alt+f to format code
3. format success, however it indented with tab instead of spaces.

data.title: EPERM: operation not permitted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:27:10.246Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 14.5.0

I am working on a folder with permissions 755 with user 'root' and group 'admin' respectively. I am (the current user) part of the 'admin' group. But, when I open this folder in code... and try to save something twice in a row, I get the following error.

A system error occured (EPERM: operation not permitted, utime '/Library/WebServer/Documents/...

I don't have this issue when working on the same folder from another editor like sublime. I have tried to run code as 'admin' and seem to solve the problem... however, I am greeted with a warning message that says it is not recommended to run code as admin. So what do I do?

data.title: Couldn't find a compatible version of MagicPython with this version of Code.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6

Hi, I'm one of the developers of MagicPython package. Starting with 1.6, it's not possible to install it: https://github.com/MagicStack/MagicPython/issues/61

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try to install MagicPython extension.
2. An error "Couldn't find a compatible version of MagicPython with this version of Code." appears.

data.title: cmd-shift-num to change editor tab
data.body: It'd be great if one could hit eg. cmd-shift-1 to switch to the first tab of the current editor. Or configure it as such so that cmd-shift-1 would select the first editor group. I struggle a lot with not being able to intuitively change tabs with cmd-[num].

data.title: 1.6+ Version has problem hitting breakpoints on transpiled code (ES6/Babel)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 (1.6.1 as well) - Using the new '**outFiles**' option (instead of the deprecated 'outDir')
- OS Version: windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Using a ES6/Babel project, transpile, and use source maps in debug configuration
2. Add breakpoint
3. Try to hit breakpoint

Observed:
-Hit breakpoint, but on the wrong line.  (used to work fine in previous versions of VSCode < 1.6)

Note: using '**outDir**' never hits any breakpoints.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.7.0-insider (c613e1bddce6a544fdf7fcfe2fc0a59626d8195d, 2016-10-17T06:06:36.370Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-43-generic, Ubuntu 16.04
- Extensions: EditorConfig.EditorConfig-0.3.3, Tyriar.lorem-ipsum-1.0.0, Tyriar.sort-lines-1.1.0, Tyriar.terminal-tabs-0.0.6, Tyriar.theme-glacier-0.0.10, be5invis.vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark-1.1.4, cssho.vscode-svgviewer-1.2.0, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.8, felipecaputo.git-project-manager-0.1.15, gerane.Theme-Wombat-0.0.2, ms-vscode.csharp-1.4.1, ms-vscode.typescript-javascript-grammar-0.0.4, rebornix.nova-0.0.5, robinbentley.sass-indented-1.1.0, ryu1kn.annotator-0.10.1

I don't think anyone would expect otherwise since a 20% height editor is unusable. If necessary to implement this it may make sense to have the command focus the panel when maximized?

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Show terminal panel
2. Toggle maximize panel
3. Click editor, the panel remains maximized

Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13898

data.title: Allow for triggering breakpoints when a watch condition is met

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Allowing for expressions in the `watch` block of the code debugger is really helpful! But it would be even better if it was possible to trigger a breakpoint automatically if the expression or evaluates to `true` (or changes, whatever is easier).

[Visual Studio has a similar feature](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa295838%28v=vs.60%29.aspx#_core_setting_a_breakpoint_when_an_expression_is_true) for reference.

data.title: C++ symbol search and other features not working on Linux install
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.10.0-327.36.1.el7.x86_64 (Scientific Linux 7)
- Extensions: ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2

I have used Visual Studio code for quite a few versions on both Windows and Linux. For some reason, none of the symbol database features seem to work on my Linux install. Right-clicking on any symbol or include file only shows "Change all Occurrences", and not peek/go to definition. This works great on Windows. I haven't seen anything in the documentation  that says this feature is Windows-only. Am I missing something?

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to any C++ source file.
2. Right click on C++ symbol.
3. Note missing options in right-click menu related to symbol

data.title: ${fileBasename} with extension, any variable without extension?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
_From @bayesrule on October 17, 2016 1:39_
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Window 7

Hi,

When using cl.exe in VS Code for C++, without other specification the output program is automatically named as {fileNameWithoutExt}.exe. In current VS Code, we already have ${fileBasename} with extension and ${fileExtname} (the extension). Is it possible to add another variable without the extension?

Below is an example in my launch.json file.

``` json

{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "C++ Launch (Windows)",
            "type": "cppvsdbg",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/${fileBasename}.exe",
            "args": [],
            "stopAtEntry": false,
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "environment": [],
            "externalConsole": false
        },
        {
            "name": "C++ Attach (Windows)",
            "type": "cppvsdbg",
            "request": "attach",
            "processId": "${command.pickProcess}"
        }
    ]
}

```

It doesn't work since the "program" property will end up with foo.cpp.exe

Many thanks!

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-cpptools#289_

data.title: Console should not say 'no suggestions' if the debug adapter doesn't support completions
data.body: If `supportsCompletionsRequest` is not returned from initializeRequest, it might look better if the 'no completions' popup is not shown when the user presses ctrl+space. It looks like the debug adapter is trying to show completions and failing.

data.title: JS code within HTML file does not comment correctly with 'editor.action.commentLine' key binding
data.body:
### system
- VSCode Version: 

```
Version 1.6.1
Commit 9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
Date 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z
Shell 1.3.7
Renderer 52.0.2743.82
Node 6.5.0
```
- OS Version:

```
Linux ubuntu02 4.4.0-38-generic #57-Ubuntu SMP Tue Sep 6 15:42:33 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Write some HTML and JS in a file, index.html

```
<head>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        alert(123);
    </script>
</head>
```
1. Hit `ctrl+/` or what ever `editor.action.commentLine` has been mapped to
### expected

```
<head>
    <script type="text/javascript">
       // alert(123);
    </script>
</head>
```
### got

```
<head>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        <!-- alert(123); -->
    </script>
</head>
```

Same happens for trying to comment CSS within `<style>` tags.

Could possibly be the same for other languages such as PHP within HTML files?
